net.sourceforge.nite.time

Class ClockFace

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.awt.Component
      • java.awt.Container
        • javax.swing.JComponent
          • javax.swing.JInternalFrame
            • net.sourceforge.nite.time.ClockFace
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants

    public class ClockFace
extends javax.swing.JInternalFrame
    A control-strip for playing through time in NXT containing play / pause / forward / rewind buttons, a speed slider and a progress slider. Original implementation Judy Robertson; Rate slider by Dennis Hofs; Other work by Jonathan & Jean.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • acceptTimeChange

        public void acceptTimeChange(double systemTime)
        We're the king of time, we'll only accept time changes using setClockFaceTime - i.e. explicitly not from other timehandlers

        public void broadcastRate()
        change the rate of play of all the known media players

      • registerMaxTime

        public void registerMaxTime(int max)
        Called by registered displays to allow the slider to be set correctly.

      • getMaxTime

        public int getMaxTime()

        Returns the maximum time. If the maximum has not yet been registered with registerMaxTime(), this method will return -1.

        Returns:
        the maximum time or -1

      • setSyncRate

        public void setSyncRate(int milliseconds)
        set the rate at which the clock attempts to synchronize with its TimeHandlers. The default is 200 milliseconds (5 times a second). If you set this too low, you'll find degradation in performance!

      • setSlaveMode

        public void setSlaveMode(boolean sm)
        set this clock face as a slave not master of the current time.

      • slaveMode

        public boolean slaveMode()
        return this clock's mode: if true, we're not giving out our time as the master time, but polling a media signal instead
